articles.title: AI can spark creativity — if we ask it how, not what, to think
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 13 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00049-2Studies aiming to maximize human creativity demonstrate that people work best when buoyed up by others who show them new ways to innovate.
articles.content:
Artificial intelligence has the potential to become a creative partner for researchers. Bots might be useful for triggering and batting around ideas, visualizing concepts in fresh ways or exploring information in different domains. However, in practice, the opposite is often true — bots flatten creativity.

Can AI be truly creative?

As a researcher who has spent 30 years studying human creativity, I think I know why. When a scientist feeds a data set into a bot and says “give me hypotheses to test”, they are asking the bot to be the creator, not a creative partner. Humans tend to defer to ideas produced by bots, assuming that the bot’s knowledge exceeds their own. And, when they do, they end up exploring fewer avenues for possible solutions to their problem.

The answer, in my view, is not to swerve away from using AI. Instead, researchers should learn how to use bots to boost their creativity.

I’ve been working with a test of rapid creative thinking called the divergent association task (DAT), which I think points to a way forwards. Participants have four minutes to come up with ten nouns that differ from each other semantically as much as possible. This is a hard task. Once someone thinks of ‘queen’, for example, they tend to call to mind related words such as king or knight — a phenomenon known as thought anchoring.

Most participants assume that if they ask a bot to perform this test, it will outperform them. But my colleagues and I have found that, on average, bot and human scores are about the same (D. Wang et al. Nature Hum. Behav. https://doi.org/hbhxbp; 2025).

Does using ChatGPT change your brain activity? Study sparks debate

By contrast, preliminary follow-up work shows that if participants ask the bot for a process with which to improve their performance, their own scores skyrocket. The bot proposes two steps. First, think of ten word categories — transportation, electronics, mammals and so on. Second, pick one word from each category. This process diminishes thought anchoring and preserves diversity of thought across participants, who each choose different word categories. The innovator and the bot are now partnering.

This experiment suggests that, when collaborating with bots, people should ask not what to think, but how to think. Work on human creativity backs up this idea.

Human creativity is often a concoction of blind alleys, detours and serendipity. But beneath the apparent chaos, studies have revealed some general principles for maximizing creativity in groups.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on research demonstrating how AI can be used as a creative partner to significantly enhance human creativity by guiding thought processes rather than providing direct answers. This represents a meaningful breakthrough in human-AI collaboration with broad implications for innovation and problem-solving across many fields.
articles.personality_title: AI boosts creativity when it guides how to think, not what to think
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Artificial intelligence (AI) can help people come up with new ideas, but often it ends up limiting creativity because people rely too much on AI’s direct answers.

**What happened** – Researchers tested a creative thinking exercise where people had to name ten very different words in four minutes. When participants asked AI for ideas directly, AI performed about the same as humans. But when participants asked AI for a method to improve their thinking, their creativity scores improved a lot. The AI suggested first choosing ten different categories, then picking one word from each category. This helped people think more broadly and avoid sticking to similar ideas.

**Impact** – This shows that AI can be a helpful partner in creativity by teaching people how to think differently, rather than giving them specific answers. It changes how humans and AI can work together, making AI a tool to guide thinking processes and encourage more original ideas.

**What's next step** – Researchers will likely explore more ways AI can support creative thinking across different tasks and fields. This approach could lead to new tools that help people solve problems in smarter, more creative ways.

**One-sentence takeaway** – AI improves human creativity best when it suggests how to think, not what to think.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’IA stimule la créativité en guidant comment penser, pas quoi penser
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’intelligence artificielle (IA) peut aider à trouver de nouvelles idées, mais souvent elle limite la créativité car les gens s’appuient trop sur ses réponses directes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont testé un exercice de créativité où il fallait nommer dix mots très différents en quatre minutes. Quand les participants demandaient des idées directement à l’IA, celle-ci performait à peu près comme les humains. Mais quand ils demandaient à l’IA une méthode pour améliorer leur réflexion, leurs résultats ont beaucoup augmenté. L’IA a proposé de choisir d’abord dix catégories différentes, puis de prendre un mot par catégorie. Cela a aidé les participants à penser plus largement et à éviter des idées trop proches.

**Impact** – Cela montre que l’IA peut être un partenaire utile en créativité en apprenant aux gens comment penser autrement, plutôt qu’en donnant des réponses précises. Cela change la façon dont humains et IA peuvent collaborer, faisant de l’IA un outil pour guider la pensée et encourager plus d’idées originales.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont probablement explorer plus de façons dont l’IA peut soutenir la pensée créative dans divers domaines. Cette approche pourrait aboutir à de nouveaux outils aidant à résoudre les problèmes de façon plus intelligente et créative.

**Phrase-clé** – L’IA améliore la créativité humaine surtout quand elle suggère comment penser, pas quoi penser.
articles.personality_title_es: La IA impulsa la creatividad al guiar cómo pensar, no qué pensar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La inteligencia artificial (IA) puede ayudar a generar nuevas ideas, pero a menudo limita la creatividad porque las personas dependen demasiado de sus respuestas directas.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores probaron un ejercicio creativo donde las personas debían nombrar diez palabras muy diferentes en cuatro minutos. Cuando los participantes pedían ideas directamente a la IA, esta rendía más o menos igual que los humanos. Pero cuando pedían a la IA un método para mejorar su pensamiento, sus puntajes de creatividad aumentaron mucho. La IA sugirió primero elegir diez categorías distintas y luego escoger una palabra de cada categoría. Esto ayudó a pensar de forma más amplia y evitar ideas similares.

**Impacto** – Esto muestra que la IA puede ser un buen compañero de creatividad al enseñar cómo pensar diferente, en vez de dar respuestas específicas. Cambia la forma de trabajar entre humanos e IA, convirtiendo a la IA en una herramienta que guía el pensamiento y fomenta ideas originales.

**Próximo paso** – Es probable que los investigadores exploren más maneras en que la IA pueda apoyar el pensamiento creativo en distintas tareas y áreas. Este enfoque podría crear nuevas herramientas para resolver problemas de forma más inteligente y creativa.

**Frase clave** – La IA mejora la creatividad humana mejor cuando sugiere cómo pensar, no qué pensar.

articles.title: Do their ears hang low? The genetics of dogs’ adorable floppy ears
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 13 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00071-4Scientists are just beginning to understand the signals that determine the length of dogs’ ears.
articles.content:
Evolution and breeding have wrought a wide variety of ear lengths in our canine companions.Credit: Getty

A gene that is important for human hearing could determine whether a dog’s ears are pendulous like a basset hound’s or stubby like a rottweiler’s, according to a genetic analysis of more than 3,000 dogs, wolves and coyotes.

The study, presented on 11 January at the Plant and Animal Genome Conference in San Diego, California, found that DNA variants near a gene called MSRB3 are linked to ear length in dogs. The results were also published in December in Scientific Reports1.

Scratching an itch

The project was inspired by Cobain, a gregarious, nine-year-old American cocker spaniel whose hobbies include morning swims in a local creek and following people from room to room. One day, Anna Ramey, an undergraduate working in a canine genetics laboratory at the University of Georgia in Athens, gazed at her dog Cobain’s long, floppy ears and wondered: why?

Dog family tree reveals hidden history of canine diversity

She took the question to her colleagues, and the project was born. “We realized that people had studied ear carriage before — like pointy, erect ears versus floppy, dropped ears,” says Tori Rudolph, a geneticist at the lab. “But no one had looked at ear length in dogs.”

The length and carriage of dog ears vary widely from breed to breed. Some of this evolved naturally: short, upright ears are thought to lose less heat than long, droopy ones, and canines from cold climates tend to have smaller ears than do those that hail from warm regions.

But selective breeding has also shaped dog ears. The basset hound’s long ears are said to boost its hunting acuity by sweeping scents towards its nose, whereas a German shepherd’s upright ears might slightly enhance its hearing.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about the genetics behind dog ear length, which enhances understanding of canine biology and evolution. This research has broad interest and potential implications for genetics and animal breeding, providing meaningful knowledge to the general public and scientific community.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover gene linked to dogs’ floppy ear length
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Dogs have many different ear shapes and sizes, from long floppy ears to short, upright ones. These differences come from both nature and how humans have bred dogs over time.

**What happened** – Researchers studied the DNA of over 3,000 dogs, wolves, and coyotes and found that a gene called MSRB3 is connected to how long a dog’s ears are. This discovery was shared at a genetics conference and published in a scientific journal.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have found a specific gene that affects ear length in dogs. Understanding this gene helps explain why some dogs have long, droopy ears like basset hounds, while others have short ears like rottweilers. It also shows how genes influence traits that have been shaped by both nature and breeding.

**What's next step** – Researchers may use this knowledge to learn more about how genes affect other dog features or how animals adapt to their environments. It could also help breeders make informed decisions when choosing traits in dogs.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A gene important for hearing in humans also plays a key role in determining how long dogs’ ears are, revealing new insights into canine genetics and evolution.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques découvrent un gène lié à la longueur des oreilles tombantes des chiens
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les chiens ont différentes formes et tailles d’oreilles, des longues oreilles tombantes aux oreilles courtes et dressées. Ces différences viennent à la fois de la nature et de la sélection par l’homme.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont étudié l’ADN de plus de 3 000 chiens, loups et coyotes et ont trouvé qu’un gène appelé MSRB3 est lié à la longueur des oreilles des chiens. Cette découverte a été présentée lors d’une conférence scientifique et publiée dans un journal.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’un gène spécifique est identifié comme influençant la longueur des oreilles chez le chien. Comprendre ce gène aide à expliquer pourquoi certains chiens ont des oreilles longues et tombantes comme le basset hound, tandis que d’autres ont des oreilles courtes comme le rottweiler. Cela montre aussi comment les gènes influencent des traits façonnés par la nature et la sélection.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs pourraient utiliser cette découverte pour étudier comment les gènes affectent d’autres caractéristiques des chiens ou comment les animaux s’adaptent à leur environnement. Cela pourrait aussi aider les éleveurs à choisir les traits des chiens de façon plus éclairée.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un gène important pour l’audition chez l’humain joue aussi un rôle clé dans la longueur des oreilles des chiens, offrant de nouvelles connaissances sur la génétique canine et l’évolution.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren gen vinculado a la longitud de las orejas caídas en perros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los perros tienen muchas formas y tamaños de orejas, desde orejas largas y caídas hasta orejas cortas y erguidas. Estas diferencias provienen tanto de la naturaleza como de la cría selectiva por parte de los humanos.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores analizaron el ADN de más de 3,000 perros, lobos y coyotes y encontraron que un gen llamado MSRB3 está relacionado con la longitud de las orejas en los perros. Este hallazgo fue presentado en una conferencia de genética y publicado en una revista científica.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se identifica un gen específico que afecta la longitud de las orejas en perros. Entender este gen ayuda a explicar por qué algunos perros tienen orejas largas y caídas como los basset hound, mientras otros tienen orejas cortas como los rottweiler. También muestra cómo los genes influyen en rasgos moldeados por la naturaleza y la cría.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores podrían usar este conocimiento para aprender más sobre cómo los genes afectan otras características de los perros o cómo los animales se adaptan a sus ambientes. También podría ayudar a los criadores a tomar decisiones informadas sobre las características deseadas.

**Frase clave** – Un gen importante para la audición en humanos también juega un papel clave en la longitud de las orejas de los perros, revelando nuevas ideas sobre la genética y evolución canina.
